【考法 1】 vi. 蹒跚： to walk unsteadily
【例】If animal spirits flagged衰退 or liquidity-preference surged汹涌, the pace of investment would falter, with no obvious market force to restore it.
【近】 lurch, stagger, stumble, teeter, totter, wobble
【考法 2】 vi. 犹豫，踌躇： to be unsteady in purpose or action, as from loss of courage or confidence
【例】 Mr. Garrison never once faltered in his demand that slavery be unconditionally abolished.
【近】 balance, halt, hesitate, vacillate, waver
【派】 faltering adj. 犹豫的
【记】 fall + er 倒下的人，走路总象快要倒下的人→踉跄
【另】 totter 蹒跚, 踉跄，摇摇欲坠
